caption: TABLE I: Comparison of Statistics and Properties: GoogleEarth, CityTopia, and Previous Datasets. Only annotated images are counted. “Ext.” stands for “Extendable”, indicating whether the dataset can be easily expanded following the current data generation pipeline. “3DM.”, “Sem.”, and “Inst.” refer to “3D Model”, “Semantic”, and “Instance”, respectively.
description: This table compares the Google Earth and CityTopia datasets with several other publicly available datasets used for 3D scene generation.  It details the number of images, number of cities represented, total area covered, data source (real or synthetic), whether the data includes lighting conditions (day and/or night), available viewpoints (street or aerial), and the types of annotations included (2D and 3D semantic and instance annotations). The 'Extendable' column indicates whether the dataset can be easily expanded using similar methods to those described in this paper.

caption: TABLE II: Quantitative Comparison. The best values are highlighted in bold. Note that InfiniCity is not included in this comparison as it is not open-sourced.
description: This table presents a quantitative comparison of different methods for 3D and 4D scene generation, specifically focusing on the metrics used to evaluate the quality of generated images and videos.  The comparison includes Fréchet Inception Distance (FID), Kernel Inception Distance (KID), VBench score, depth error (DE), and camera error (CE). Lower FID and KID scores, and higher VBench scores indicate better image quality. Lower DE and CE scores indicate better 3D geometry and multi-view consistency.  InfiniCity is excluded from this comparison due to its non-open-source nature.

caption: TABLE III: Quantitative Comparison of Ubounded Layout Generator (UIG). The best values are highlighted in bold. The generated images are centrally cropped to a size of 4096×\times×4096.
description: This table presents a quantitative comparison of different unbounded layout generators (ULGs), evaluating their performance in generating city layouts.  The comparison is based on Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) and Kernel Inception Distance (KID), which are metrics that measure the quality and diversity of generated images. Lower FID and KID scores indicate better performance. The generated images were centrally cropped to 4096x4096 pixels before evaluation. The table allows for a direct comparison of the three ULGs:  IPSM, InfinityGAN, and the proposed ULG from the CityDreamer4D model.

caption: TABLE IV: Quantitative Comparison of Building Instance Generator Variants. The best values are highlighted in bold. Note that “Inst.” and “Pos.Enc.” refer to “Instance Labels” and “Positional Encoding”, while “G” and “L” denote “Global Encoder” and “Local Encoder”, respectively.
description: This table presents a quantitative comparison of different variations of the Building Instance Generator (BIG), a key component of the CityDreamer4D model.  The variations are created by systematically altering the BIG's architecture and components, such as using or omitting instance labels, different positional encoding methods (SinCos vs. Hash), global vs. local encoders, and combinations thereof. The evaluation metrics used are FID, KID, Depth Error (DE), and Camera Error (CE).  Lower values for FID, KID, DE, and CE generally indicate better performance.  The table helps to understand the impact of each architectural choice on the overall quality and accuracy of the generated building instances.

caption: TABLE V: Quantitative Comparison of Vehicle Instance Generator Variants. All metrics are computed on the vehicle-only city from the CityTopia dataset. The best values are highlighted in bold. Note that “Can.” and “Pos.Enc.” refer to “Canonicalization” and “Positional Encoding”, while “G” and “L” denote “Global Encoder” and “Local Encoder”, respectively.
description: This table presents a quantitative comparison of different variations of the Vehicle Instance Generator (VIG), a crucial component of the CityDreamer4D model.  The variations are created by systematically modifying components such as the presence of a global or local encoder, the use of canonicalization, and the type of positional encoding (hash or sinusoidal). All metrics (FID, KID, Depth Error (DE), Camera Error (CE)) are calculated using a vehicle-only city from the CityTopia dataset. The best performance across all metrics for each VIG variation is highlighted in bold, enabling a direct comparison of each configuration's impact on the model's ability to generate realistic and consistent vehicle instances.
